bugzilla.short_desc: CVE-2024-39338 helix: axios: Server-Side Request Forgery [fedora-all]

long_desc.thetext:
More information about this security flaw is available in the following bug:

https://bugzilla.redhat.com/show_bug.cgi?id=2304369

Disclaimer: Community trackers are created by Red Hat Product Security team on a best effort basis. Package maintainers are required to ascertain if the flaw indeed affects their package, before starting the update process.
Can you provide me with more information on this? I can't see why "axios", a javascript library for HTTP requests, can affect this package.

I have a local git branch tracking this release, but I need gix 0.69 and gix-features 0.39 before I can proceed.

It might be possible to build this against gix 0.66 by patching dependencies and reverting the code changes in https://github.com/o2sh/onefetch/commit/287571cafb70b8657c30626b76956876217c2e80, but either way, there is one other blocker:

 Problem 9: nothing provides requested (crate(tokei/default) >= 13.0.0~alpha.7 with crate(tokei/default) < 14.0.0~)

Updating rust-tokei to an alpha release (and adding a rust-tokei12 compat package to provide a stable version of the command-line tool) is a possibility: version 12 is very old now, version 13 has been in alpha development for four years, and rust-onefetch is the only thing that depends on tokei as a library. However, doing so will require a new package, rust-table_formatter, bug 2335210.

I have a local git branch tracking this release, but I need gix 0.69 and gix-features 0.39 before I can proceed.

It might be possible to build this against gix 0.66 by patching dependencies and reverting the code changes in https://github.com/o2sh/onefetch/commit/287571cafb70b8657c30626b76956876217c2e80, but either way, there is one other blocker:

 Problem 9: nothing provides requested (crate(tokei/default) >= 13.0.0~alpha.7 with crate(tokei/default) < 14.0.0~)

Updating rust-tokei to an alpha release (and adding a rust-tokei12 compat package to provide a stable version of the command-line tool) is a possibility: version 12 is very old now, version 13 has been in alpha development for four years, and rust-onefetch is the only thing that depends on tokei as a library. However, doing so will require a new package, rust-table_formatter, bug 2335210.

bugs.title: CVE-2024-56201 helix: Jinja has a sandbox breakout through malicious filenames [epel-9]

bugzilla.short_desc: CVE-2024-56201 helix: Jinja has a sandbox breakout through malicious filenames [epel-9]

blocked.short_desc: CVE-2024-56201 jinja2: Jinja has a sandbox breakout through malicious filenames

long_desc.thetext: Jinja is an extensible templating engine. Prior to 3.1.5, a bug in the Jinja compiler allows an attacker that controls both the content and filename of a template to execute arbitrary Python code, regardless of if Jinja's sandbox is used. To exploit the vulnerability, an attacker needs to control both the filename and the contents of a template. Whether that is the case depends on the type of application using Jinja. This vulnerability impacts users of applications which execute untrusted templates where the template author can also choose the template filename. This vulnerability is fixed in 3.1.5.
This project is not affected as it does not bundle the source code of jinja2.

(In reply to fedepell from comment #5)
> This project is not affected as it does not bundle the source code of jinja2.

Are you sure you have commented on the correct bugzilla? This is the main bug shared between all the components that ship the vulnerable source code.
Lumir: you are right, sorry for this :/ Bugzilla notifications are a bit of a mess (IMO at least ;)) . Sorry again! (my comment was intended for the jinja2-time module)
